alt_statements.statement: As someone who runs a small medical equipment business and has Cherokee roots, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we depend on a healthy land and climate for our children’s future, just as much as we depend on good jobs right now. Climate policy should be aggressive about cutting emissions and protecting water and land, but it also needs to support small businesses and workers with incentives, training, and help transitioning to cleaner technologies. Our community has lived with the land for generations; if we do this right, we can honor that tradition while building a modern, fair economy.

As a husband and father working in manufacturing, I believe climate policy has to protect the environment without destroying the jobs and industries that support families like mine. We should invest in cleaner technologies and energy efficiency, but changes must be gradual, realistic, and guided by science and common sense, not ideology. If regulations become so strict that factories move overseas or shut down, we end up hurting both our economy and, in many cases, the global environment. The right balance is encouraging responsible stewardship of creation while keeping businesses competitive and workers employed.

Working with cement and concrete, I see firsthand how much our industry contributes to emissions, so I don’t think we can treat environmental protection as optional or secondary to growth. We should push hard for stricter climate standards and invest in cleaner technologies, even if that means short-term costs, because long-term economic health depends on a stable climate and sustainable practices. Smart policy can help businesses transition—offering incentives for greener materials and processes—so workers like me aren’t left behind while we build a low-carbon economy.

As a moderate and a mom, I think we need climate policies that protect the environment without forgetting that families like mine depend on stable jobs and affordable energy. We should invest in practical, science-based solutions—like cleaner technologies and energy efficiency—that support long-term economic growth rather than stifle it. I don’t believe in extreme measures on either side; instead, we should aim for steady, realistic progress that preserves the planet for our kids while keeping communities and local businesses strong.

I think we’ve got to take climate change seriously, but we also can’t just pull the rug out from under people who depend on steady jobs and affordable energy. To me the right balance is investing in cleaner technologies and energy efficiency in a way that supports American businesses and workers, rather than burdening them with sudden, heavy regulations. I’m fine with strong environmental standards as long as they’re practical, phased in over time, and based on solid data instead of politics.

As someone who’s seen a lot of change over the years and cares deeply about nature—especially the birds and the small patch of garden I tend—I think we can’t afford to treat environmental protection as optional. At the same time, I know people need steady jobs and affordable energy, especially working families and retirees on fixed incomes. Climate policy should push hard for cleaner energy and conservation, but do it in a way that supports workers through retraining, protects vulnerable households from rising costs, and gives businesses time and incentives to adapt rather than simply punishing them.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and has watched bird populations shift over the decades, I’m convinced that environmental protection has to set the boundaries within which economic growth can occur, not the other way around. We should aggressively invest in clean energy, conservation, and climate resilience, treating them as engines of innovation and long-term prosperity rather than burdens on the economy. Short-term profit that degrades ecosystems is simply bad economics, because it passes enormous costs—health, disaster recovery, biodiversity loss—onto future generations. A smart climate policy is one that prices pollution accurately, protects vulnerable communities, and channels market forces toward sustainable growth.

As someone who works in a public school kitchen and is raising kids, I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because our health and our children’s future depend on clean air, water, and a stable climate. But that doesn’t mean sacrificing economic growth—it means investing in green jobs, better school infrastructure, and clean energy in our communities so working families like mine can benefit. Smart climate policy should protect the planet while creating good, stable jobs and making sure low-income and Native communities aren’t left behind.

As someone raising kids and working in healthcare, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need policies that do both, because climate change directly affects people’s health, jobs, and cost of living. I support strong climate regulations and investments in clean energy and infrastructure, but they should be designed to protect working families from sudden job losses or big spikes in everyday expenses.

Coming from Honduras and now working in construction, I’ve seen how jobs and development can lift people up, but also how careless building and pollution can damage the land and communities that depend on it. Climate policy should prioritize environmental protection as a long‑term investment, setting strong regulations and incentives for clean technologies, while helping workers and businesses transition so they aren’t left behind. Economic growth that destroys the planet or sacrifices poorer communities isn’t real progress, so we need policies that tie public and private profit to sustainability and social responsibility.

In my kitchen, if you use up all the ingredients today and don’t think about tomorrow, soon you have nothing to cook with—same with the environment and the economy. We need climate policies that protect the air, water, and land our kids will live with, but also give small businesses like my restaurant clear rules, support to upgrade equipment, and time to adapt so we don’t get forced to close our doors. For me, good policy is like a balanced menu: you cut waste, use energy efficiently, and invest in cleaner tools, while still keeping enough profit to pay workers and raise a family.

I think we should protect nature a lot because animals and trees can’t fix themselves if we ruin everything, and I really like playing outside. But I know people need jobs and money too, so we should make rules that stop really bad pollution while helping people get new kinds of jobs, like building clean energy stuff. God gave us the Earth to take care of, not just to use up, so we shouldn’t trade a healthy planet for quick money.

As someone who works in business process improvement, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply intertwined rather than opposing goals. We should design climate policy that aggressively reduces emissions and protects ecosystems, but does so by incentivizing innovation, clean energy investment, and more efficient business practices. With smart regulations, clear carbon pricing, and strong public-private partnerships, we can transition to a low-carbon economy that actually creates high-quality jobs and long-term prosperity. As a Democrat and a Catholic, I also see this as a moral responsibility to care for creation and ensure a livable planet for future generations.

At my age, I’ve seen enough boom-and-bust cycles to know that “jobs versus the environment” is a false choice—there are no good jobs on a dying planet. We need aggressive climate policies that put environmental protection first, and then design the economy around that reality: invest in clean energy, retrain workers, and hold corporations accountable instead of letting them write the rules. Economic growth is fine, but it has to be sustainable, equitable, and measured by community well-being, not just quarterly profits.

As someone who spent a lifetime organizing in the community, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as enemies, but I do think the planet’s limits have to set the rules of the game. We should invest heavily in clean energy, public transit, and green jobs so working families—especially in Latino and immigrant neighborhoods—can benefit from the transition instead of being left behind. If we damage the climate beyond repair, any short-term economic gains won’t mean much to our grandchildren, so growth has to serve sustainability and justice, not the other way around.

As someone who’s worked hard my whole life for a modest paycheck, I don’t think protecting the environment and having a strong economy should be treated like an either-or choice. We need climate policies that move us toward clean energy and stricter environmental standards, but they should also protect workers and keep basic goods affordable for people like me. With smart regulation, investment in green jobs, and help for communities that rely on older industries, we can have both a healthier planet and a fairer economy.

I think we should protect nature first, because God made the earth and all the animals and plants, and we’re supposed to take care of them. Grown‑ups can still make money and have jobs, but they should do it in ways that don’t make the air dirty or hurt people’s health, especially kids and people who are already having a hard time. If we work hard and use our imaginations, we can invent better, cleaner things so both the earth and people’s jobs can be safe.

I think we’ve got to protect the land and water God gave us, but we can’t do it by killing off the jobs that feed our families. Climate policy should focus on common‑sense steps—like improving efficiency, encouraging cleaner tech in manufacturing, and promoting American energy independence—without drowning businesses in regulations. We should move toward cleaner practices, but at a pace that keeps factories open, paychecks coming, and working people like me able to support our kids.

I think climate policy should protect the environment, but it can’t do it in a way that kills jobs or makes life way more expensive for families like mine. We should focus on practical solutions like investing in cleaner technology, encouraging businesses to innovate, and using our energy resources responsibly instead of pushing extreme regulations that hurt the economy. I believe we can be good stewards of God’s creation while still supporting strong economic growth and American workers.

As someone who worked in computer systems design and still believes in practical, market-based solutions, I think climate policy should protect our environment without strangling the economy that working families and retirees depend on. We should encourage innovation in cleaner technologies, nuclear energy, and efficient industry through incentives rather than heavy-handed regulation, while making sure we don’t ship jobs overseas to countries with lower standards.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when companies and politicians ignore the environment, and we can’t keep kicking that can down the road just to squeeze out a little more profit. We need strong climate policies that push businesses toward cleaner technologies and energy, with support to help workers and small companies transition so people don’t get left behind. Protecting the environment and growing the economy isn’t an either-or thing anymore; long-term economic health depends on having clean air, stable weather, and a livable planet for the next generation.

I think we should take care of the Earth because God made it, but we also need to make sure grown-ups can keep their jobs so they can buy food and toys for their kids. Maybe we can use cleaner energy and plant more trees so the air is better, without shutting down everything that families need to earn money.

I don’t think we should have to choose between a decent job and a livable planet, especially when people my age are the ones who’ll deal with the worst of climate change. Working construction, I see how much money gets thrown around on big projects, so there’s no excuse not to invest in cleaner tech, better building standards, and green jobs that still pay well. Climate policy should put strict limits on pollution and carbon, but also help workers and companies transition so regular people don’t get screwed while we clean things up.

I like when people plant trees and keep the air and water clean so animals and kids like me can be healthy and play outside. Grown‑ups should make rules so companies don’t hurt the planet too much, even if it means they have to change how they do things or spend more money.

As a young dad working in a pretty physical job, I want my kids to grow up in a world with clean air and a stable climate, but I also need policies that don’t wipe out working-class jobs or jack up our basic costs overnight. I think we should push hard on clean energy and efficiency, with strong environmental standards, but pair that with serious investment in retraining, good union jobs, and support for communities that depend on old industries. Environmental protection should set the direction, and economic growth should come from building the new green economy in a way that doesn’t leave regular families behind.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put off taking care of things, and the planet is no different—if we don’t protect the environment now, there won’t be much “economy” left for the next generations. I think climate policy should put environmental protection first, but it also needs to support working people and small businesses like my little salon with help to transition—affordable clean energy, grants, and incentives to make greener choices. Economic growth is important, but it should come from cleaner, smarter work, not from cutting corners on the air we breathe and the water we drink.

I think we’ve got to stop acting like we have to choose between the planet and people having jobs, because climate policy can create new kinds of work and businesses if we do it right. As someone working retail and not exactly rolling in money, I want strong environmental protections, but I also need policies that make clean energy and green tech affordable and create decent-paying jobs for regular folks, not just the rich.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we prioritize short-term profit over the air we breathe and the water we drink, and it’s always the most vulnerable who pay the highest price. I believe environmental protection has to come first, and our economic growth should be measured by how well we care for people and the planet—through good green jobs, cleaner communities, and policies that look beyond the next quarterly report.

As someone who has spent a career in national security and international affairs, I see climate policy as a strategic issue where environmental protection and economic strength must reinforce, not undermine, each other. We should pursue market-driven innovation—like advanced energy technologies and modernized infrastructure—that reduces emissions without sacrificing American jobs or energy security. Overly aggressive regulations that handicap our economy or increase dependence on foreign adversaries are counterproductive, but ignoring environmental risks would also be irresponsible to our children’s future. The right balance is pragmatic, evidence-based policy that protects our land and resources while keeping the United States prosperous, competitive, and secure.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because without a healthy planet there won’t be any economy or future for kids like me. But I also get that people need jobs, so climate policies should help create new kinds of work, like clean energy or green construction, especially for families who don’t have a lot of money. If we’re fair about it and listen to everyone, we can grow in a way that doesn’t destroy the air, water, and parks we all share.

As someone who’s spent a life teaching and now volunteers in a community garden, I think we’ve misunderstood the choice: a healthy environment is the foundation of any real, lasting economy. Climate policy should put environmental protection first—rapid emissions cuts, protection of ecosystems, and strong regulations—while supporting workers and communities through a just transition into green jobs and more localized, sustainable industries. We’ve tried putting short-term profit ahead of the planet for decades, and it’s left us with unstable weather, fragile supply chains, and hollowed-out communities; it’s time economic growth serves ecological limits, not the other way around.

Working in healthcare, I see every day how environmental conditions directly affect people’s health, especially the most vulnerable, so for me environmental protection has to be the starting point, not an afterthought. That said, I don’t think it’s “environment versus economy” so much as shifting our economy toward clean energy, green jobs, and sustainable practices that create long-term stability instead of short-term profit. Climate policy should set firm environmental limits—on emissions, pollution, and resource use—and then encourage innovation and investment within those boundaries. In the long run, a healthy environment is the foundation of any strong economy, not a luxury we trade away for growth.

I make my living pulling materials out of the ground, so I know firsthand that modern life and good jobs depend on energy and resources—but I also spend a lot of time outdoors with my family and don’t want to see the land or air ruined. Climate policy should push for cleaner, more efficient technology and responsible practices in industries like mine, but it has to be gradual, realistic, and pro-growth so it doesn’t shut down good-paying jobs or jack up costs for working families.

I think we’ve got to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to keep an eye on people’s livelihoods and the strength of our local businesses. Climate policies should focus on practical, cost‑effective steps—like improving energy efficiency, encouraging innovation in cleaner technologies, and using market incentives—rather than heavy-handed regulations that hurt working folks and small clinics like the ones I work with. We ought to aim for gradual, realistic changes that protect the environment while keeping energy affordable and our economy competitive.

As someone who has made a good living in real estate and is grateful for the opportunities this economy has given me, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we can and must pursue both together. Strong climate policies that encourage energy-efficient buildings, green infrastructure, and resilient communities not only protect God’s creation but also create stable, long-term value for homeowners, businesses, and neighborhoods. For me, the right balance means prioritizing environmental safeguards and public health while giving businesses clear rules and incentives to innovate, rather than letting short-term profits dictate our future.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how our environment shapes people’s bodies and minds, I don’t think environmental protection and economic growth should be treated as competing goals. Climate policy should put planetary and community health first, and then build economic growth around that through green jobs, clean energy, and support for workers and small businesses making the transition. Long term, an economy that destroys its environmental foundation is neither ethical nor stable—real prosperity means clean air, safe water, and resilient communities for everyone.

Como alguien que trabaja moviendo mercancías todo el día y ve cuánta gasolina, empaques y desperdicio usamos, pienso que seguir con el mismo modelo económico es simplemente insostenible. No creo que proteger el medio ambiente y crecer económicamente sean opuestos: si invertimos fuerte en energía limpia, transporte público eficiente y empleos verdes bien pagados, podemos cuidar el planeta y crear mejores oportunidades para gente trabajadora como yo. Lo injusto es que las comunidades inmigrantes y de bajos ingresos sufrimos más la contaminación y el cambio climático, así que las empresas que más contaminan deberían pagar su parte para financiar esta transición. Para mí, una economía sana en el siglo XXI es una donde la naturaleza tiene derechos, las personas tienen trabajo digno y el crecimiento se mide también en calidad de vida, no solo en ganancias.

Como mujer que vive de manera sencilla y cuida el hogar, veo que la economía debe servir primero a las personas y a la creación de Dios, no al revés. Para mí, las políticas de clima deben proteger la tierra y el agua, aunque eso signifique cambiar la forma en que se gana dinero, pero con apoyo real para las familias trabajadoras y los inmigrantes que dependen de esos empleos. El crecimiento económico tiene valor solo si no destruye la casa común que dejamos a las próximas generaciones.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see how polluted rivers can become clean again and how jobs can disappear when we don’t plan ahead, I don’t think we should treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites. We should invest heavily in clean energy, conservation, and green infrastructure, creating stable, good-paying jobs while preserving the climate for our grandchildren and the natural world I cherish in my garden. If we insist on short-term profits over long-term sustainability, we’ll end up paying far more—economically, morally, and spiritually—down the line.

At my age, having spent a career in community development and conservation, I don’t buy the idea that we have to choose between a healthy environment and a healthy economy—they rise or fall together. Smart climate policy should put strong protections in place for our air, water, and land, while investing in clean energy, public transit, and resilient infrastructure that create good local jobs and support working families. If we plan ahead and listen to both scientists and communities, especially those most affected, we can grow the economy in a way that doesn’t mortgage our grandkids’ future.

As someone who works in retail and tries to live in an environmentally conscious way, I don’t think we should treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites. We should push for policies that transition us to clean energy and sustainable practices, while also investing in green jobs and retraining so regular workers aren’t left behind. Climate change will be far more expensive in the long run if we ignore it, so smart climate policy is actually a foundation for lasting economic stability, not a threat to it.

As someone who has worked many years in a supermarket and lived through times of scarcity, I believe we must protect the environment, but we cannot ignore the need for stable jobs and affordable food. Climate policies should be gradual and practical, focusing on energy efficiency, waste reduction, and cleaner technologies that businesses can realistically adopt without closing or laying off workers. I respect the Confucian idea of balance and responsibility, so we should not damage nature for short-term profit, but we also should not push policies so fast that ordinary working families suffer. A careful, step‑by‑step approach that encourages conservation and innovation, while protecting the livelihoods of small businesses and low‑income people, is the best path.

Working in home health care, I see how extreme heat and pollution already hurt the most vulnerable, so I believe strong environmental protection has to come first, with smart planning to protect jobs and keep costs manageable. We shouldn’t accept the old idea that we must choose between a healthy planet and a strong economy; instead, we should invest in clean energy, public transit, and building upgrades that create good local jobs while cutting emissions.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we wreck the planet, any short-term economic growth won’t matter in the long run. At the same time, climate policies should create good jobs and help low-income and Black communities, like mine in Alabama, so people aren’t forced to choose between paying bills and doing the right thing for the earth.

We need a climate policy that protects our land and communities without kneecapping the economy that keeps this country strong. I support reasonable environmental protections based on solid science and cost-benefit analysis, but not sweeping regulations that kill American jobs and make us dependent on foreign energy. A strong domestic energy sector—fossil fuels included, with cleaner technology where practical—keeps us secure and prosperous while we gradually transition where it makes sense. The priority should be American workers, national security, and practical, market-driven solutions—not ideology.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we chase short-term profit and ignore long-term costs, especially in communities like mine that have borne the brunt of pollution. We shouldn’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as enemies—good climate policy can create stable, decent jobs, especially in clean energy and infrastructure, while keeping our air and water safe. The balance ought to lean toward protecting the planet and public health first, and then designing smart investments and transitions so working people and retirees aren’t left holding the bag.

I think we should protect nature first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be a safe place for people or businesses anyway. Grown-ups should use money and inventions to make cleaner energy and less pollution, even if it costs more at the start, so that kids like me can still have forests, animals, and fresh air when we’re older.

As a teacher, I can’t help but think about what kind of world we’re leaving to our students, so I believe environmental protection has to be a top priority, even if it means reshaping how our economy works. That said, climate policy should also support workers and local communities, especially through investments in green jobs, public transit, and education so people aren’t left behind. I don’t see it as environment versus economy; a healthy, stable climate is the foundation of long-term economic well-being.

As someone who’s young, active, and planning for a long future on this planet, I think protecting the environment has to come first, and our economic growth should adapt around that reality. Climate change is already hitting vulnerable people hardest, and it’s unfair and short-sighted to treat the planet like it’s disposable just to boost short-term profits. That said, we should use this transition to create new green jobs and industries, so it’s not “environment vs. economy” but a different kind of economy that’s cleaner, fairer, and more sustainable.

I think we have to protect the environment first, because if the planet gets too messed up, there won’t even be an economy or jobs to grow into when I’m older. Grown-ups and companies should still be able to make money and invent cool new stuff, but they should do it in ways that don’t pollute so much or waste energy. It seems fair that rich businesses and countries pay more to clean things up and switch to cleaner energy, instead of kids like me having to live with worse weather and disasters we didn’t cause.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we wreck the planet now there won’t be any future economy for my generation to grow up into. But I also get that people need jobs and money, so I’d rather see us invest in cleaner technologies and energy that create new kinds of work instead of just shutting everything down.

As someone who teaches and spends most of my time thinking and writing, I see climate policy as a long-term investment rather than a short-term cost. We shouldn’t frame environmental protection and economic growth as opposites; a healthy, stable climate is the foundation for any sustainable economy. I support strong regulations and public investment in clean energy and green infrastructure, especially when they create good jobs and protect vulnerable communities. In the long run, choosing the environment is choosing a more resilient and fair form of growth.

As a young mom, I want my kids to grow up with clean air, safe water, and healthy food, so I believe caring for the environment is a responsibility we have to God’s creation and to our children. At the same time, I know many families like mine are on tight budgets, so climate policies should focus on practical, affordable solutions—like supporting clean energy jobs, helping people insulate their homes, and making healthy, eco-friendly options cheaper—not on sudden rules that make it harder for parents to provide for their kids.

As someone running a small advertising agency and raising young kids, I want strong climate policies that prioritize environmental protection while giving businesses like mine clear, stable rules to innovate and grow. We shouldn’t treat climate action and economic growth as opposites—smart investments in clean energy, green infrastructure, and sustainable practices can create good jobs and new markets. I’d support policies that phase out the worst polluters, reward companies that cut emissions, and ensure working families aren’t stuck with the bill. Ultimately, protecting the planet my kids will inherit is more important than short-term profits for big corporations, but it’s on government and industry to make the transition fair and practical.

At my age, after a lifetime running a business, I’ve learned that a healthy economy depends on a healthy planet, so climate policy should treat environmental protection as the foundation, not an afterthought, of growth. We should invest aggressively in clean energy, efficiency, and green jobs so businesses can thrive while cutting pollution, especially in working-class and Latino communities that often breathe the dirtiest air. As a Christian, I see caring for creation as a moral duty, and as a Democrat, I believe government should set strong standards but also help small businesses and workers transition fairly. The balance is not choosing one over the other, but using smart policy to make protecting the environment the engine of long-term economic prosperity.

I think climate policy should lean more toward protecting the environment, because my generation is the one that’s going to be stuck living with the damage if we don’t act now. At the same time, we can’t ignore people who depend on certain jobs, so the goal should be to create new, greener industries and training programs that let workers transition without being left behind. Economic growth shouldn’t come from trashing the planet; it should come from investing in clean energy, public transit, and sustainable tech that actually makes life better and fairer for everyone.

I believe we need a practical balance where we protect our land, air, and water without strangling the businesses and workers that keep our communities going. Climate policies should focus on realistic, cost‑effective steps—like encouraging energy efficiency, cleaner technologies, and responsible use of resources—without crushing small businesses or driving up prices for working families. I’d rather see incentives and innovation than heavy-handed regulations that hurt jobs and the economy.

We need a sensible balance that protects God’s creation without strangling the jobs and businesses hardworking people depend on. I support practical, market-based steps to reduce pollution and encourage cleaner technologies, but I don’t believe in heavy-handed regulations that drive up energy costs for families and small companies. Climate policy should focus on innovation, efficiency, and responsible use of our resources, not on punishing the very workers who keep this country running.

I think we need a common‑sense balance where we protect the environment without wrecking people’s jobs and paychecks. I’m all for cleaner air and water, but I don’t trust massive regulations that shut down businesses and drive up prices for working folks like me. We should focus on practical steps—like encouraging new technology, making energy production cleaner and more efficient, and using American resources—so we can grow the economy and take care of the planet at the same time.

As a dad and a software developer at a public university, I see climate policy as an investment in my kids’ future and in long-term economic stability, not a drag on growth. We should prioritize strong environmental protections while driving innovation—things like clean energy research, green infrastructure, and retraining programs—so that workers and families aren’t left behind. Economic growth that’s built on burning out our planet is fake prosperity; smart climate policy should aim for jobs, health, and sustainability at the same time.

As someone working in tech and planning to be in the workforce for decades, I think climate policy has to prioritize environmental protection first, because the economic growth we care about isn’t worth much on a destabilized planet. That said, I don’t see this as a zero-sum tradeoff: smart regulation, carbon pricing, and investment in clean infrastructure and innovation can create new industries and high-quality jobs, including in software and data. The balance, to me, is setting firm environmental limits and then using market mechanisms and technology to grow within those boundaries, rather than sacrificing the climate for short-term profits.

As someone raising kids and running a tiny daycare business here in Ohio, I don’t buy the idea that we have to choose between good jobs and a livable planet—those two ought to go hand in hand. Climate policy should put strong protections on our air, water, and climate first, then support workers and small businesses in making the transition with fair funding, training, and incentives. I want my children, and the kids I care for, to grow up with both economic security and clean parks, streams, and skies—not one at the expense of the other.

As someone who teaches and does research at a university, I see climate policy as an investment in our long-term economic and social stability rather than a drag on growth. We should prioritize strong environmental protections—especially rapid decarbonization and conservation—while channeling public and private resources into clean energy, green infrastructure, and workforce retraining so that communities and working families aren’t left behind. A healthy environment is the foundation for a durable economy, and smart policy can align climate responsibility with innovation, job creation, and greater equity.

As someone who runs a small business and is very focused on health and wellness, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply connected, not opposed. Climate policy should prioritize aggressive emissions reductions, clean energy, and conservation, while offering strong support and incentives to help workers and small businesses transition. We need to stop treating short-term profit as more important than long-term public health and a livable planet. A smart, just climate policy can grow the economy by investing in green infrastructure, local jobs, and healthier communities.

As a mom, a teacher, and someone who wants my kids to grow up with clean air and safe weather, I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, but in a way that supports working families and creates good jobs. We shouldn’t accept the idea that we have to choose between a healthy planet and a strong economy—investing in renewable energy, green infrastructure, and energy‑efficient schools can create stable, middle‑class jobs while cutting pollution. Environmental rollbacks that boost short‑term profits but harm children’s health and future are not worth it, especially when we have the technology and resources to grow our economy sustainably.

I think climate policy should put environmental protection first, because if we wreck the planet, there won’t be an economy or a future for kids like me anyway. But I also think we need to create new green jobs and training so people, especially in working-class and diverse communities, aren’t left behind as things change. Instead of pretending we have to choose between the planet and paychecks, we should invest in clean energy, public transit, and sustainable agriculture that protect the environment while giving people real opportunities.

We need to protect the environment, but we can’t do it in a way that wrecks jobs, public safety budgets, and working people’s cost of living. I’d support climate policies that push practical innovation—like cleaner energy, efficiency, and better infrastructure—as long as they’re grounded in real-world data, don’t crush small businesses, and keep America energy independent.

As someone who works every day with people’s emotional well‑being, I see climate policy as a moral and mental health issue as much as an economic one. We should prioritize strong environmental protections, especially for vulnerable communities, and design economic growth around clean energy, green jobs, and sustainable practices rather than short‑term profit. A healthy planet is the foundation for any just and lasting economy, and public policy should reflect that truth.

As someone who’s spent years working with families and communities, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need climate policies that create good, stable jobs while safeguarding the world our kids will inherit. I support strong regulations on pollution and big investments in clean energy, public transit, and sustainable agriculture, especially when they prioritize working people and vulnerable communities. In the long run, an economy that destroys its own natural foundations isn’t real growth; real prosperity means healthy air, water, and soil, and a fair shot for every family to thrive.

Working in the power industry, I see every day that we can’t pretend the economy and the environment are separate—when storms knock out our grid or heat waves spike demand, people’s bills, jobs, and safety are all on the line. Climate policy should push aggressively toward cleaner energy and efficiency, but with strong protections for workers and low-income communities so the costs of transition don’t fall on those who already struggle. As a Democrat and a Catholic, I believe we have a moral duty to care for creation and for each other, which means investing in green technology, modernizing infrastructure, and training workers for new roles instead of clinging to outdated, polluting systems. Economic growth should come from building a more sustainable, resilient future, not from sacrificing our health and our planet for short-term profit.

I believe we need a practical balance where we protect the environment without strangling the businesses and workers that keep our communities going. Climate policy should focus on common-sense measures—like improving efficiency, reducing waste, and encouraging innovation—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive up costs and threaten jobs, especially in industries that depend on physical goods like mine. As a conservative and a Catholic, I see stewardship of the earth as important, but so is protecting people’s livelihoods and keeping our economy strong enough to support families and the vulnerable.

I think we need a climate policy that protects the environment without kneecapping the jobs and businesses regular families depend on. I believe in common-sense measures—like improving energy efficiency, supporting cleaner technology, and encouraging responsible use of resources—but not heavy-handed regulations that drive up prices or send work overseas. Good stewardship of God’s creation matters, but so does keeping the economy strong so I can provide for my family and my kids have opportunities in the future.

As a conservative small-business attorney, I believe sound climate policy must protect our environment without crippling the economic engine that funds innovation, jobs, and American prosperity. We should prioritize market-based solutions, technological advancement, and incentivizing cleaner energy over heavy-handed regulation that harms small firms and working families. Environmental standards should be realistic, cost-effective, and grounded in solid science, with clear, predictable rules so businesses can plan and invest confidently. In short, we must be good stewards of God’s creation while ensuring that climate policy strengthens, rather than undermines, our free-market economy and national competitiveness.

I like when we plant trees and keep the air clean so we can play outside and not get sick. Grown-ups should make money and have jobs, but they shouldn’t break the world God made for us. I think we should use smart ideas and new things so we can have both good jobs and a safe place to live.

I think we should protect nature first, because if we ruin the air, water, and animals, there won’t be a good world for people to work and make money in later. Grown‑ups should make rules so companies don’t pollute too much, but also help them use cleaner energy and new ideas so people can still have jobs and take care of their families.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see our seasons change and our community face droughts and wildfires, I believe we can’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we have to grow in ways that heal, not harm, the planet. Strong climate policy should push us toward clean energy and conservation, creating good, stable jobs and healthier communities rather than clinging to old industries that damage our air, water, and long‑term future.

I believe we need a climate policy that protects the environment without strangling the businesses and workers who keep our communities going. We should focus on practical, market-driven solutions—like encouraging energy efficiency, supporting innovation in cleaner technologies, and using incentives instead of heavy-handed regulations—so we can keep our air and water clean while still growing jobs and keeping costs reasonable for families. Environmental goals matter, but they have to be balanced with economic reality and respect for people’s livelihoods.

I believe we should protect the environment, but in a way that doesn’t crush small businesses and working people like me who depend on steady work to pay the bills. Climate policies should focus on realistic steps—like incentives for more efficient equipment and less waste—that help us save energy and money without forcing expensive regulations on cleaners, tradespeople, and small contractors. For me, the right balance means caring for God’s creation while still allowing families and small businesses to grow and thrive.

As someone who runs an outpatient center and sees every day how economic stability affects people’s health and dignity, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as competing goals—we need climate policy that drives innovation, creates good jobs, and safeguards public health at the same time. I support strong, science-based regulations on emissions and incentives for clean energy, paired with targeted support for workers and communities that might be disrupted, so we’re not asking people to choose between their livelihoods and a livable planet.

Where I’m from, you learn pretty quick that if you strip the land bare for a quick buck, you pay for it down the road—same goes for the climate. I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites; if we invest in clean energy, sustainable materials, and circular business models, we can create good-paying jobs that don’t poison our air and water. Climate policy should put strict limits on pollution and carbon, but give businesses clear incentives and support to innovate so workers and communities—especially in places like Tennessee—aren’t left holding the bag. In my mind, long-term prosperity depends on treating a stable climate and healthy ecosystems as the non-negotiable foundation of the economy, not an optional extra.

As someone who runs her own travel accommodation business and has seen firsthand how beautiful — and fragile — our world is, I believe environmental protection and economic growth must go hand in hand, not be treated as opposites. Climate policy should prioritize strong protections for the environment while supporting incentives and clear guidelines that help businesses adapt and innovate, rather than simply punishing them. If we damage the very places people travel to experience, we undermine long-term prosperity; investing now in cleaner energy, resilient infrastructure, and sustainable tourism is both a moral responsibility and smart economics.

As someone who has watched this country change over nearly nine decades, I believe we have a duty, under God, to be good stewards of the earth—but also a responsibility to protect the livelihoods of working families. Climate policy should focus on practical, incremental measures that encourage innovation in cleaner energy and conservation without strangling our industries with excessive regulation or driving up costs for ordinary Americans. We need a balanced approach that respects both the environment and the dignity of work, rather than sweeping mandates that sound good on paper but hurt people in practice.

As someone who has lived long enough to see how both jobs and landscapes can vanish, I don’t believe we should treat environmental protection and economic growth as enemies. We owe it to future generations—and to God’s creation—to put strong limits on pollution and invest in clean energy and green jobs, especially for workers and communities that might be left behind. A just climate policy should prioritize protecting the most vulnerable people and ecosystems, while guiding the economy to adapt and thrive in more sustainable ways.

As someone who works in architectural and civil design and cares a lot about health and how we live day‑to‑day, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we can and should design our growth to be sustainable. Smart climate policy should aggressively reduce emissions and protect ecosystems while incentivizing green jobs, energy‑efficient buildings, and cleaner infrastructure that keep people employed and communities thriving.

As someone who works in home care and sees how extreme heat and pollution affect my elderly patients, I believe climate policy has to put environmental protection first, but in a way that doesn’t abandon working families. We can and should grow the economy by investing in clean energy, public transit, and climate-resilient infrastructure, especially in communities of color and immigrant communities like mine that are often hit hardest. Rather than treating jobs and the environment as opposites, we should create good, green jobs, retraining workers and supporting small businesses so that protecting the planet also means improving people’s daily lives.

I believe we have a responsibility, as stewards of God’s creation, to protect the environment, but we must do it in a way that doesn’t cripple our economy or burden working families and small businesses. Climate policy should focus on practical, market-based solutions—like encouraging innovation in cleaner energy and efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs and raise costs. We ought to move toward cleaner technologies steadily, with careful cost–benefit analysis, so we leave a livable world to our grandchildren without undermining the prosperity that made this country strong.

Working in restaurants, I see firsthand how small businesses and workers can get squeezed, so I don’t think climate policy should just slam on the brakes for the economy. But we can’t ignore climate change either, because the people with the least money — including a lot of service workers like me — are usually hit hardest by extreme weather and rising costs. I think we should push hard for clean energy and efficiency, but do it in a way that protects jobs, retrains workers, and helps low- and middle-income families afford the transition. Environmental protection and economic growth don’t have to be opposites if we’re smart and fair about how we design policy.

Working in construction sales, I see firsthand how much our livelihoods depend on a strong economy, but I also know that if we don’t take climate change seriously, we’re just setting ourselves—and our kids and grandkids—up for bigger costs down the line. We should be investing aggressively in cleaner, more efficient building practices and infrastructure, creating good-paying jobs while cutting emissions. To me, that’s not anti-business; it’s smart long-term planning and lines up with the Jewish value of tikkun olam—leaving the world better than we found it.

I think we need to protect the environment, but we also have to be practical and not destroy people’s livelihoods in the process. Climate policies should focus on gradual, realistic changes—like encouraging cleaner energy and better efficiency—without putting too much burden on small businesses, working families, and people on fixed incomes like me.

I think we should take care of the Earth first because it’s like our home that God gave us, and if we hurt it too much, kids like me won’t have clean air or safe places to play. Grown-ups should still be able to have jobs and make money, but they should do it in ways that don’t pollute so much, like using cleaner energy and making less trash.

As someone working in e-commerce and raising kids in a tight-budget household, I don’t buy the idea that we have to choose between a livable planet and people having jobs. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, but it has to do it by investing in clean energy, green infrastructure, and job training so regular workers—especially in Black communities—aren’t left behind. We should hold big corporations most accountable for cutting emissions, while using public money to create good-paying, future-proof jobs in neighborhoods like mine. That way we’re protecting our kids’ future climate and their economic future at the same time.

I worked my whole life in the energy industry, and I’ve seen how reliable power and good jobs keep communities going, but I’ve also watched the seasons and the bird populations in my garden change in ways that worry me. Climate policy should push companies to clean up their operations and invest in cleaner technologies without suddenly pulling the plug on the workers and towns that depend on them. We need a gradual, practical transition that protects the environment, supports new industries and retraining, and keeps energy affordable and reliable for ordinary people.

As a business owner and a mom, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need smart climate policies that drive innovation, create good jobs, and keep our kids healthy. I support strong, science-based regulations and incentives that push companies toward cleaner energy and more sustainable practices, while giving them clear, stable rules so they can plan and grow. If we invest in green technologies and resilient infrastructure now, we protect both the planet and long-term economic opportunity, especially for future generations.

At my age, having watched rivers catch fire in the 60s and air in our cities become briefly unbreathable, it’s obvious to me that economic growth built on environmental ruin is a short-term illusion, not real prosperity. Climate policy should put environmental protection first as the non‑negotiable boundary within which a fair, innovative, and jobs‑rich economy can flourish—much like the safety standards we long ago accepted in other realms. We should invest heavily in clean energy and resilient infrastructure, not just to avert catastrophe, but to ensure that future generations inherit both a livable planet and a dynamic economy, rather than being forced to choose between them.

As someone who works every day with families trying to build stable, healthy lives, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—real prosperity for my kids’ generation depends on a livable planet. Climate policy should push hard for clean energy and conservation, but do it in a way that protects working families, creates good green jobs, and supports communities in transition rather than leaving them behind.

I think we need to protect the land and water God gave us, but we also can’t ignore that folks need steady jobs and affordable gas and groceries to take care of their families. Climate policies should focus on common‑sense solutions—like encouraging cleaner energy and better efficiency—without shutting down industries overnight or driving up costs for working people. We should move toward a cleaner future, but do it in a way that supports American workers, keeps our economy strong, and doesn’t leave small towns and low‑income families behind.

I think we should take care of the Earth first, because without clean air, water, and safe weather, people can’t really work or make money anyway. Grown‑ups should use smart ideas and new inventions so businesses can still grow, but in ways that don’t hurt animals, trees, or the people who are already having a hard time. My parents teach me that in Islam we are guardians of the planet, so climate rules should protect nature while also helping families have good jobs and homes.

I spent a career keeping the lights on and I know firsthand that you don’t just flip a switch and walk away from the grid or the jobs it supports. We’ve got to protect the environment because there’s no economy on a dead planet, but we also need practical, step-by-step policies that keep power reliable and affordable while we transition to cleaner sources. I support investing in modern, resilient infrastructure and cleaner technologies, as long as we do it in a way that doesn’t abandon workers or communities that have depended on traditional energy for generations.

I think we need a climate policy that treats environmental protection and economic growth as partners, not opponents. As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and also works in a practical, bottom-line world, I believe we should invest in cleaner technologies and energy efficiency in ways that create stable, good-paying jobs rather than sudden disruptions. If we set clear, predictable rules and give businesses incentives to innovate, we can protect the natural world I care about without sacrificing the livelihoods of working families.

As someone who’s seen industries come and go in North Carolina, I don’t think we can treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposing sides anymore—they have to move in tandem. We should invest heavily in clean energy, efficiency, and conservation, not only because it’s our moral responsibility as stewards of God’s creation, but because it can create stable, good-paying jobs and new industries. Climate policy should put strict limits on pollution while supporting workers and communities in the transition, so we’re not leaving people behind as we do the right thing for future generations.
